How I Am Studying Lithuanian
entry.content:
CAVEAT

This post is titled "How I Am Studying" rather than "How I Learned" Lithuanian, for two reasons:
  1. Firstly, I do not yet speak Lithuanian fluently.
  2. Secondly, even when I attain fluency in the language, I will continue to study it according to this method, which has proven itself time and time again.

OVERVIEW: LEARNING LANGUAGE THE HARD WAY

Most students of a language want as quickly as possible to build up their vocabularies, but when it comes to the mechanics of the language -- grammar, syntax, morphology, etc. -- the general approach ranges from picking up bits and pieces along the way to paying lip service to it.
My method may be called "Learning Lithuanian the Hard Way" because I invested about one hundred hours in studying Lithuanian grammar, syntax, morphology, and pronuncation.  Now, after three months of intense preparation, I am starting to focus on vocabulary, writing, and speaking.
This method requires discipline, patience, and attention to detail; it may be likened to the physical training of an elite athlete, and as such in almost all cases requires the supervision of a language coach.

INTRODUCTION: WHAT IS LANGUAGE?

For our purposes, all languages are composed of speaking and listening, to which we add writing and reading.  Bear in mind that the written language merely represents the spoken language, for this insight will help you greatly in understanding the forms of words, pronunciation, and elegant arrangement of words in a sentence.
These four primary language activities and their variations are ranked in order of difficulty:

  1. Reading: The easiest. The entire context is available, there is no pressure to produce language, nor is there time pressure.
  2. Listening: The second easiest. Most of the context is available in the conversation, there is no pressure to produce language and time pressure is minimal.
  3. Writing: The second hardest. No context is available for ascertaining the meaning of individual words and there is pressure to produce the language, but there is no time pressure.
  4. Speaking: The hardest. No context is available for ascertaining the meaning of individual words, there is pressure to produce language, and there is intense time pressure.
If we expand this into the variations of these activities, the ranking is roughly the same:

Reading (Alone) Silently

The easiest language activity is reading silently, for there is no time pressure nor do you have to make the effort of producing the sounds of the language.

Reading Alone Out Loud

The second-easiest language activity is reading out loud without an audience.  There is still no time pressure, you can read as slowly as you like, and you can repeat words, phrases, sentences, and even entire paragraphs as many times as you like without any pressure from your audience.

Reading Out Loud to a Private Audience

The third-easiest language activity is reading out loud with a private audience (as opposed to a public audience, which places much greater pressure on you), which can be either another person or a recording device.  With a private audience present, there is the most minimal time pressure, but you can still read very slowly and carefully.  With a private audience you begin to feel the pressure of performance, and you may initially feel stage fright.  The only solution is to keep on practising in front of a sympathetic private audience until you get over it.

Listening to a Recording or Private Reading with the Text to Hand

The easiest form of listening is where you have total control of the audio and can follow along on the page.  For example, listening to an audiobook and reading the book at the same time.  In this manner you both see and hear the language, can control the pace, re-listen to a section, make notes on the page, etc.  The time pressure is minimal and there is no pressure to produce the language or interact with someone.  Another alternative is a sympathetic native speaker reading out loud to you slowly and clearly.  If your reader knows what he is doing, this is far superior to a recording.

Listening to a Recording or Private Reading without the Text to Hand

This is significantly harder than reading along with the audio, but only insofar as you do not recognise the words.  As you train your ear to the natural rhythm of the language and recognise common phrases and constructions, listening will become easier, for you will naturally infer the meaning of unfamiliar words.

Listening to an Interlocutor

The next step up from listening to scripted speech is to make sense of a conversation partner.  As you have the context of the conversation, you more easily infer the meaning of unfamiliar words, and a sympathetic speaker will speak slowly and simply; nevertheless, you have to keep up with the conversation.

Listening in on a Conversation

The most difficult form of listening is making sense of speech that is not directed at you, for which you do not have the context.  This includes listening to other people's conversations, watching films in the language (made easier by subtitles), etc.  Because you are not the conversation partner of a sympathetic speaker, his speech is typically faster, the words are less clearly pronounced, and you can not signal to him to repeat or explain an unfamiliar word.

Writing with the Aid of a Dictionary

Any kind of writing requires you to do all the heavy lifting of constructing sentences, i.e. not only summoning the words, but inflecting them and arranging them.  In writing there is no time pressure to speak of, and with a dictionary, you can write sentences mostly in Lithuanian and then translate the remainder.

Writing without the Aid of a Dictionary

This form of writing demands the creative use of your vocabulary: you have to reduce your ideas to their essence in order to express in the simplest terms possible.

Private conversation with a Sympathetic Interlocutor

The hardest of the primary language activities is speaking, for it entails all the pressures of producing language and must be done in real time.  A sympathetic conversation partner can lighten your load by giving you time to find your words and supply you with the key word here and there.

General Conversation and Public Speaking

The second-most difficult language activities are speaking freely in a conversation and public speaking.  The difficulty of each depends on how comfortable you are in front of a crowd, but the cognitive load is the same: You have to produce language in real time without assistance.

Getting Angry at Someone

The hardest language activity is getting into an argument with someone.  To all the other stressors of producing language is added the heat of emotion, which transforms a private conversation into the equivalent of a public performance with a hostile audience.

RESOURCES

The online resources are so paltry, and the Lithuanian language is so complicated, that learning to speak Lithuanian autodidactically is practically impossible without supreme motivation, talent, deep knowledge of language, and an advanced method of study.

Having said that, the following have proven enormously useful to me:
  • Google Translate (USE WITH EXTREME CAUTION): https://translate.google.com/
  • The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian grammar: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_grammar
  • The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian declension: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_declension
  • The Debesƒólis Lithuanian course: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/courses/lt
  • Cooljugater for Lithuanian Verbs: http://cooljugator.com/lt/list/all
  • The Accentuator Tool from Vytauto Did≈æiojo Universiteto: http://tekstynas.vdu.lt/page.xhtml;jsessionid=B9B35DD0D70596608023D1295B2BF16C?id=accentuator-tool
  • This declension tool: http://morfologija.lt/
  • Google Lithuania: https://www.google.lt/
  • Lithuanian Wiktionary: https://lt.wiktionary.org/
  • And most significantly, the Lithuanian translation of the Little Prince, which is my language-learning rosetta stone: http://ebiblioteka.mkp.emokykla.lt/kuriniai/mazasis_princas/,format.pdf
There is also an audiobook version of this text "Ma≈æasis Princas", but you'll have to hunt around for it.

TOOLS

  • A5 exercise book
  • Black pen
  • Blue pen
  • Red pen
  • Green pen
  • Highlighter
  • Small ruler
  • Flash cards
  • Flash card container

GETTING STARTED

Step One: Study the grammar

I printed out and read through the entirety of these articles
The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian grammar: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_grammar
The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian declension: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_declension
The Debesƒólis Lithuanian course: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/courses/lt
I read and re-read until I was satisfied I understood broadly how Lithuanian works -- noun declension, verbal conjugation, adjectival inflexion, participles, etc.

Step Two: Find Your Rosetta Stone

'Le Petit Prince' by Antoine de Saint-Exupery is marvellously well suited to language learning.  It is a simple and short, and contains simple dialogue, repetition, core vocabulary, and advanced vocabulary.  It is accessible to both children and adults and can be read many times over without becoming stale.  I have read it in French, English, German, Italian, Hebrew, Dutch, and have used it extensively to learn Lithuanian.
If the 'Le Petit Prince' is not for you, use any text you like, but make sure it is simple enough for you to read in a foreign language and enjoyable enough to be read a hundred times over.

Step Three: Add Stress Marks to Your Rosetta Stone

Added to all the other things that make Lithuanian difficult is the seemingly unpredictable pattern of its floating stress placement.  My initial plan was to listen to the audiobook and note the stresses for the entire book, which would be an excellent exercise, but very laborious.
Luckily, I was able to feed the entirety of the text through the Accentuator Tool from Vytauto Did≈æiojo Universiteto: http://tekstynas.vdu.lt/page.xhtml;jsessionid=B9B35DD0D70596608023D1295B2BF16C?id=accentuator-tool
I then pasted the accentuated text into a document and turned it into a book: I printed the whole text and had it bound.

Step Four: Extract the Verbs*

* The essential part of speech in all Indo-European languages is the verb, for it is the engine of the sentence; if you are studying Hungarian or Finnish for example, the nouns seem to contain more essential information.  When in doubt, focus on the verbs.

I read the Introduction and Chapters One and Two, and with the aid of Google Translate identified all of the verbs.  On flash cards I recorded the essential details of each verb and the passage in which the verb was used; on the back of each flash card I recorded all the variations of the verb that can be produced by adding prefixes.  In this manner I recorded 109 core verbs, totalling around 500 different verbs.

Step Five: Read Your Rosetta Stone Out Loud As Much As Possible

I have continued to read and re-read the book "Ma≈æasis Princas" out loud.  Most of the time, I do so on my own, but on weekends I read to my beautiful fianc√©e, who at first put up with all my mistakes and mispronunciations, and now enjoys my readings.  This step runs in parallel with all the remaining steps.

Step Six: Conjugate Your Verbs

In my exercise book, I conjugated all 109 of my newly acquired core verbs.  This task took me about 40 hours and I can now confidently conjugate any regular verb in Lithuanian that I have the essential information for -- infinitive, third-person singular, third-person plural.

Step Seven: Nominal Declension Drills

I returned to the flash cards, identified the nouns in the passages I recorded, and wrote all their forms -- singular and plural.

Step Eight: Adjectival Inflexion Drills

I returned to the flash cards, identified the adjectives in the passages I recorded, and wrote out all their forms -- singular and plural, masculine and feminine.

Step Nine: Learn the Numbers

I studied this lesson on numbers on Debesƒólis: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/lesson/temp/221

Step Ten: Learn the Pronouns

I studied this lesson on pronouns on Debesƒólis: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/lesson/temp/223

Step Eleven: Participle Declension

Lithuanian participles are much easier to understand in light of noun declensions and adjectival inflexions.  They are simply verbs that are used as adjectives and adverbs, and thus inherit both the information pertaining to verbs (tense, number) and to adjectives. (Declension, gender, number)

Step Twelve: Review

After three months and about 100 hours of preparation, planning, and exercises, I am now ready to start "using" Lithuanian.  I still need to learn some irregular verbs, nouns, and adjectives, and there remain some aspects of Lithuanian grammar that I have not practised enough to use confidently on the fly, but I now have a solid foundation.  I have profound understanding of mechanics of the language, and can construct grammatically correct sentences.  Without ever focusing on learning new words in Lithuanian, I have nevertheless acquired a good foundational vocabulary and must now put it to use in writing.

Step Thirteen: Write Essays, Learn from My Mistakes

The best way to expand my vocabulary is to write about diverse topics in Lithuanian and to learn the words that I have to look up in the dictionary.  This way, instead of learning words that I will not use, I learn only the words that I need to know and am likely to use frequently.  This shall be my core vocabulary on which my expanded vocabulary is to be built.
The process for each composition is as follows:
  1. Write in Lithuanian as much as I can without a dictionary, and leave words and phrases I do not know in [brackets].
  2. With a dictionary to hand, fill in the [gaps].
  3. Submit the essay to a native Lithuanian for correction.
  4. Have the native Lithuanian re-write the essay more elegantly, with authentic Lithuanian turns of phrase.
  5. Thank the Lithuanian profusely for his time.
  6. Take note of the corrections.
  7. Study the re-written essay and learn the new words and turns of phrase.

Step Fourteen: Complete the Study of Lithuanian Grammar

I will go through whatever resources are available and make sure that I am familiar with all aspects of Lithuanian grammar.

Step Fifteen: Write, Speak, Read, and Listen.

From this point on, all that is required is to use the language as much as possible and to learn the idiom of the language.  I might continue to use flash cards, or I might just keep a notebook.  Whereas a novice of the language needs to refer to a complete table of declensions or conjugations, an expert needs only a single datum to fill in a gap in his knowledge.  Over time, I will instinctively note the particulars of new vocabulary without having to write anything down and I will get a feel for authentic, elegant turns of phrase.  This process will span the rest of my life, but I predict most of my learning will take place in the next three years.

TuriuÃÄ pasakyÃÅti, kaÃÄd nedauÃÉg paÃÄmenu iÃÄ≈° pirm≈≥ÃÉj≈≥ gyveÃÉnimo meÃÉt≈≥ A≈°kelone, prisiÃÄmenu tiÃÄk taÃÅi, kaÃÄd viÃÄskas atroÃÅdƒó labaiÃÉ svetimaÃÄ.  OÃÅras buÃÄvo labaiÃÉ karÃÉ≈°tas, m≈´ÃÅs≈≥ namaiÃÉ laÃÉbai ma≈æiÃÄ, kult≈´raÃÄ u≈æsienieÃÉti≈°ka irÃÉ ≈æmoÃÅnƒós maÃÅn atroÃÅdƒó laukiÃÄniai irÃÉ keistiÃÄ.  Prad≈æiojeÃÄ, negalƒóÃÅjau patikƒóÃÅti, kaÃÄd jieÃÉ yraÃÄ ≈æyÃÉdai.

entry.title: U≈æduotys ir Apsipirkimas
Paprasta Lietuvi≈≥ Kalba
entry.content:
Learning Lithuanian is hard.

Firstly, Lithuanian is a difficult language;

Secondly, the educational resources out there are not very good;

Thirdly, most Lithuanians, even those teaching it, don't seem quite to understand the enormous cognitive load placed upon a foreigner who tries to communicate in their language.  As soon as a student of the language shows any aptitude, a well meaning Lithuanian will throw him in the deep end and speak to him as if he is a native.  This is to be taken as a compliment, for sure, but it can be demoralising for the fainter of heart.

Taking a leaf out of C.K. Ogden's book, Basic English, I am putting together a minimalist vocabulary of Lithuanian.

BASIC Noun List
BASIC Preposition List
BASIC Conjunction List

entry.title: A≈°tuntoji Pamoka: Lai≈°kas
Pasikalbƒójimas su kirpƒóju
Penkioliktoji pamoka: Nemunas
Mastery of Lithuanian: Beginnings
entry.content:
This is my first attempt at outlining a pathway to mastery of the Lithuanian language.  I am sure that there are many more branches to be added, but I believe that if a student of Lithuanian masters the areas covered by this diagram, he will have a strong foundation on which to build his acquisition of the language.

Vocabulary

The most obvious omission from this schema is a reference to vocabulary.  This is for two reasons:
  1. The need for vocabulary is self-evident.
  2. In a highly inflected language vocabulary without a vast investment in grammar and syntax is practically useless.

Language Production

All language can be reduced to its four primary activities, in order of importance:
  1. Speaking
  2. Writing
  3. Listening
  4. Reading
The most important activity is speaking, and the value of all the others in my view is determined by the degree to which they lead to and support the development of spoken Lithuanian.
However, knowledge of the orthographic system is indispensable in learning a civilised language, and is learned most usefully when the student appreciates the give-and-take between the spoken and written forms of the language.

Diacritics

Lithuanian relies heavily on diacritics to indicate grammatical function and sound shifts, mostly on account of palatalisation.  As a foreigner, the visual prompt of diacritics is a useful stepping stone towards adoption of Lithuanian speech patterns.

Palatalisation

Lithuanian sound production is heavily influenced by palatalisation, and mastery of this feature unlocks for the student both the most important aspect of pronunciation, and makes spelling considerably more sensible as well. 

Grammar

If mastery of Lithuanian can be likened to tree, then its grammar is undoubtedly the trunk.
The most logical progression to my mind is as follows:

Nouns

Mastery of nouns will give the student a grounding in the following: 
  • Case system (nominative, genitive, dative, accusative, instrumental, locative, vocative, adessive)
  • Number (singular and plural)
  • Gender (masculine and feminine)
The concepts and declensions of nouns, especially first and second declension (-as, -a), enable the student to readily grasp the following:
  • Adjectives
  • Adverbs
  • Pronouns
  • Numbers

Verbs

Mastery of verbs will give the student a grounding in the following:
  • Tense (present, past, future)
  • Mood (indicative, interrogative, imperative, subjunctive)
  • Aspect (single block of time, frequentative)
  • Number (singular, plural)
  • Case (i.e. the case of the object of the verb)

Participles and Prepositions

Thus, with the knowledge from two main branches ‚Äî nouns and verbs ‚Äî the student of Lithuanian is armed to understand Lithuanian participles, which combine all the information of an adjective and a verb.
Also, as a natural consequence of observing prepositions, a student thus armed will have no difficulty in ascertaining that the objects of verbs and prepositions take particular cases, e.g. "ƒØ" takes the accusative, the object of "gauti" is accusative, the indirect object of "duoti" is dative, etc.

***

In my estimation, a student of Lithuanian who builds his knowledge on this grammatical foundation, with a clear view of speaking and writing Lithuanian as soon as possible, as much as possible, should suffer no serious obstacles on the path to mastering Lithuanian idiom and conventions.
